20-14 and 13-l Washington Square North, seen from a tall builsing

ans the East Side skyline. Part of the New York University

724028f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square Park - [Washington Square (South).]
724028f-a.text:
Washington Square Park,on the Northern side as seen from 97I
Washington Square 5outh.
This is a good view of the Northern part of the Park,with
Washington Arch in the center foreground. In the left background
mmay be seen the old Jefferson Market Clock Tower;a survival from
the IE70s at Sixth Avenue and IOth Street.
July I935.

723981f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West
723981f-a.folder: Washington Square & Washington Square West, Manhattan, NY

723984f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West
723984f-a.text:
Washington Arch, Washington Square, seen from the north so as to
show the Judson Memorial Baptist Church (1892) framed in the
archway, anc the fountain in the center of the park. The church
stands on the S.W. corner of Thompson Street and Washington
Square South (4th Street).
This arch was built around 1890; the wooden one designed by Stanford
White for the Centenary of President Washington's inauguratiow,
in 1889, was so well liked that it was decided to erect a permanent
arch of stone, which White also designed.
About 1925.
Ewing Galloway.
NO REPODUCTIONS.
723984f-a.folder: Washington Square & Washington Square West, Manhattan, NY

723989f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West
723989f-b.text:
Washington Square, seen from a roof at Sixth Avenue near 4th Street.
The principal New York University building is on Washington Square
East from Washington to Waverly Flaces. On the N.E. corner of
Waverly and University Places a tall apartment building is going
to be erected in 1929. The tall building north of the scuare is
the new One Fifth Avenue. To the right may be seen the new
apartment building at 32 Washington Square West, recently erected
on the site of the old Hicks-Lorc house. Behind it, on the
horison, the tower of the Consolidated Gas building, Irving Place
and 14th Street, is nearing completion.
Nearer in the foreground are the roofs of the Holley Hotel, 35-6
Washington Square West, and the old houses 37-39, which are soow
to be replaced by an apartment building. The spires in the
immediate foreground beloag to the Washington Sduare Methodist
Episcopal Church at 135 West Fourth Street. Down in the park,
to the right of the fountain, and nearer, may be seen the newly
rebuilt comfort station.
April 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
Sixth Avenue,West side,at West 4th Street,north west from Third
Street,showing the Excelsior Accordion Manafacturing Company's
building.
March 15th,1932.
P.L.Sperr,
No reproductions.

724046f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - 4th Street
724046f-a.text:
Washiwgtow Square West, from 4th Street to Washingtow Place, showing
the twin 7-story builsings of the Holley Hotel ia the center of
the block. This is one of the three original Knott hotels, and
was wamed after Alexander J. Holley, of whom a bust has stood in
Washington Square since 1890.
The 3-story builsing on the corner of Washington Place, a part of
the hotel, will be torn aown in 1930 ans replaces by the 16-story
Holley Chambers. The three houses iw the southern half of the
block will also be replaced by a tall apartment buileing.
December 28, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

723998f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 4th Street (West)
723998f-a.text:
Washington Square North, east from about 8 Washington Square.
These old reSidences contrast with the receatly erectes 21-story
apartment building on the N.E. corner of Waverly Place and
University Place, built in 1929. In the right foregrouns is
shown part of Washingtow Arch, giving a very good profile view
of Washington.
About 1931.
Ewing Galloway.
